byline.contributor: Maher Samaan reported from Beirut, and Anne Barnard from Baghdad. An employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Damascus, Syria.
byline.original: By MAHER SAMAAN and ANNE BARNARD

abstract: Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad, in televised address, acknowledges government forces are facing manpower shortages in fight against insurgents and that citizens are burdened by economic hardship; Assad maintains typical defiant tone throughout much of speech, but remarks come as striking admission for leader who has often sought to gloss over country's troubles.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad also said that the army had ceded some areas to insurgents in order to hold onto other regions deemed more important.

headline.main: Assad, in Rare Admission, Says Syria’s Army Lacks Manpower
headline.print_headline: In a Rare Admission, Assad Acknowledges That Syria’s Army Lacks Manpower

snippet: President Bashar al-Assad also said that the army had ceded some areas to insurgents in order to hold onto other regions deemed more important.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
